The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here we present a comparison of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian, with the goal of understanding the extent of the evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme, and that the genome of a myxozoan is one of the smallest reported in animals. In addition, we find that myxozoans have a reduced gene content, especially in categories related to development, cell differentiation, and cell–cell communication. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the poor. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. These results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammalian herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the potential for DNA metabarcoding to provide quantitative information about diet composition. This approach could be used to quantify diet overlap and to identify the extent to which species partition food resources. Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 5. This has led to a decrease in the effective catch per unit of effort, which is a measure of the pressure on the ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most difficult to increase. We show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather to an increase in metabolic power.

Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein that is implicated in the development of a number of neurodegenerative disorders, including multiple system atrophy (MSA). MSA is a sporadic disorder with a poor prognosis. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This study opens the door to the development of a new class of drugs that could be used to treat synucleinopathies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It controls vascular function, including blood pressure, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is designed to be both local and global in its communication, and to be robust and fast in its response. The design of the network is important for the control of vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor and respond to the pandemic. However, the data are often not available in a form that is useful for research and decision-making. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available. The data are available in a common format, and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the data can be used to monitor the pandemic, and to augment traditional public health reporting. The data and software are available to the public.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for natural products to be produced by the gut microbiome is just beginning to be explored. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, produce a variety of natural products. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to study the role of the microbiome in health and disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate to low-anxious rats during a social encounter and that this is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious rats. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides evidence for the existence of a link between anxiety and mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens.

The hemoglobin system is a key component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the human hemoglobin system. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal hemoglobin system and is down-regulated in the adult hemoglobin system. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is a key regulator of the adult hemoglobin system. Our results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a potential target for the development of therapies to treat hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. One of the major causes of cancer-related mortality is the resistance of cancer cells to the death-inducing effects of oxidative stress. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers cancer cells with resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. Mechanistically, this resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. Finally, we demonstrate that the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings have important implications for the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the most important strategy to prevent heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our study provides a mechanism of LCCB action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study may help to reduce the risk of heart failure development in patients treated with LCCBs. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but that the decline of older forests accelerated. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach is expected to be a useful tool for the development of new antibiotics. The design strategy is also expected to be applicable to the design of new drugs for other diseases. (Show more)

We introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice.

This study shows that the use of such devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The role of CTLA-4 in the control of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the control of autoimmunity, but its specific function in the control of autoimmunity is dependent on the developmental stage of the immune system.

We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be applicable to other viruses that cause diseases in humans. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of social systems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold increased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are associated with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Despite its importance, how the human brain processes language is one of the most challenging problems in cognitive science. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks that predict brain and behavior on a range of language tasks also predict brain and behavior in a task that probes language comprehension. Our results provide computational and neuroscientific evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism of language comprehension in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that we do not know how to train a neural network to be stable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they are the only ones that can be stable and compute a neural network with a given accuracy. This is a major advance in the theory of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It is also a major source of scientific and public debate. In this article, we discuss the role of a classic psychological experiment in the spread of the virus.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the causative agent has been the subject of intense research. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a human pathogen that is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are ancient relatives that have maintained their pathogenicity for millions of years. This study also provides a resource for future research on the biology of this uncultured pathogen. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the key ingredients of quantum statistical mechanics. However, the interplay between them is not fully understood. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in a class of interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step toward a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires the development of safe and effective vaccines. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. The vaccine candidate was shown to be protective in hamsters, and the vaccine strain was shown to be highly attenuated in vitro and in vivo. The vaccine candidate is currently in phase I/II clinical trials in humans. The results presented here support the development of COVI-VAC as a potential vaccine for the COVID-19 pandemic. Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is also a disease that is still present today, with a resurgence in the Middle East and Africa. In this study, we use a mathematical model to explore the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were primary vectors of plague during this period, challenging the assumption that plague was predominantly spread by rats. This study highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague and the potential for human-to-human transmission in the future.

The evolution of brain size is a topic of great interest, but it is biased by the fact that most studies use brain size as a proxy for brain function. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive abilities of animals. We show that the evolution of brain size is associated with the evolution of cognitive abilities.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes filaments is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to filaments and that filament curvature favors severing. Surprisingly, tension has no effect on ADF/cofilin binding or severing. We also find that ADF/cofilin-induced filament twist enhances severing. A simple model, which we verify experimentally, indicates that the ADF/cofilin-induced twist increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding severing in cells and for developing new strategies for controlling actin dynamics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose ingestion relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations. In addition, we show that the history of Madagascar is also reflected in the genomic diversity, with a strong influence of geography on the genetic structure of the population. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a new way to study the spread of emotions, and it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others in a variety of situations, not just in person.

The presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a common modification that has been shown to impact mRNA stability and translation. However, the impact of Ψ on translation has not been studied in a reconstituted translation system or in human cells. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu and the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain. We also show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can increase the rate of translation of Val-tRNAVal. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of Ψ in mRNA function and for developing new strategies for controlling translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and physical and mental functioning. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and health outcomes before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must respond appropriately to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This signal transduction mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pilus retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This is the first demonstration of a type IV pili-based mechanosensitive signal transduction system in bacteria. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of pili in motility and virulence, and for the development of new strategies for the control of bacterial infections. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more integrated approach to study the ecology and evolution of viruses. In this study, we demonstrate that SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is circulating in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a more integrated approach to study the ecology and evolution of viruses is needed. Our study highlights the need for a more integrated approach to study the ecology and evolution of viruses. This approach should include a focus on the human-animal interface, as well as the study of the virus in its natural reservoir. Such an approach would provide a more complete understanding of the dynamics of the virus and could lead to the development of more effective control strategies. The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper studies the reasons for the growth of large dams in the developing world and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, we show that the Aβ-burdened neuron is the primary source of an inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. This neuron-specific inflammatory response is characterized by the production of a variety of cytokines, which are known to be potent activators of microglial cells, the main immune cells in the brain. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is the primary source of the AD-associated inflammation, which may contribute to the pathogenesis of the disease.

The chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present evidence that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied for many years. We have found that the folding of this protein is a complex process that involves distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of proteins is a complex process that involves distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list will grow further as more proteins are studied by this method. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are thought to function as signaling molecules. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, RppH, also recognizes and degrades capped RNAs. Unexpectedly, RppH prefers capped substrates over their capped counterparts, and the cap is recognized by a mechanism distinct from the one used to recognize other 5′ termini. This results in a one-nucleotide shift in the position of the pyrophosphate bond, which is cleaved by RppH to generate a monophosphorylated RNA 5′ terminus. This discovery has implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as well as for the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial virulence. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with mitochondrial dysfunction and T cell exhaustion. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve immune function in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, such as quantum computing, photonics, and energy storage. However, its properties are sensitive to strain, and it is unclear how to control them. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its properties can be tuned, by strain engineering. We also show that diamond is stable against phase transitions to graphite, which is a stable allotrope of carbon. Our findings can be used to control the properties of diamond for applications. They also provide a general framework for strain engineering of other materials. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the pharmaceutical industry and the scientific community. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens. The antifungal activity of NCR044 is due to its ability to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings, followed by penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli. This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR044 and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a fundamental unit of evolution, and the process of sperm–female interactions is critical to reproductive success. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–female interactions and the extent of intersexual continuity. (Show more)

The A1 domain in VWF binds to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on platelets, in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches A1 and/or GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 100 million viral sequences. The resource is available for use in the study of viral disease associations, and is a valuable resource for the study of the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The instrument is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the instrument’s capability by conducting continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing. The observations show that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be cooler than it was in the past. However, the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is not well constrained. We present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past, based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient DNA.

K+ channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body and are important for normal physiology and pathophysiology. K+ channels are activated by membrane depolarization and inactivated by C-type inactivation. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can be induced to show C-type inactivation by a low extracellular K+ concentration together with a mutation that causes a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and can occur during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or with decreased intracellular calcium ([Ca2+]i). We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the function of K+ channels and may be useful for the development of drugs for treating diseases. (Show more)

Malaria is a devastating disease that affects millions of people each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This finding could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. (Show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and suggests that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza infection. Our findings may also have implications for the development of strategies to combat influenza virus

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes sentences. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remains largely unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal regions increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the neural basis of language and for the design of artificial intelligence.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway for the regulation of cell fate and tissue development. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated in the developing mouse embryo. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral parabrachial nucleus (LPBN) and the ventral tegmental area (VTA) induces eating in sated mice. We also show that this system is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. This system may contribute to the development of obesity, and may be a target for the treatment of this disease.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the rhizosphere would allow for the delivery of nitrogen to the plant only when needed, thus improving nitrogen use efficiency and reducing the risk of N2-fixing bacteria becoming resistant to the current suite of chemical control methods. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the rhizosphere, and we have demonstrated that this system can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in situ in barley roots. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a proof of principle for the use of transkingdom signaling to control the activity of a microbial symbiont. This approach could be extended to other microbial symbionts and to other organisms, including animals. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the large number of false alarms generated by remote-sensed deforestation monitoring. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web is an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured, dynamic, and highly sensitive acoustic sensor. The spider can hear in the air, and it can also hear through its web. The spider can also hear in the dark, because the web is illuminated by the moon and stars. The spider can hear in all directions, because the web is in all directions. The spider can hear in all places, because the web is everywhere.

The health and climate impacts of human activities are often considered separately. We show that the two can be linked, and that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical component of the global response, but the high cost of some vaccines may limit their availability in low- and middle-income countries. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein subunit vaccine candidate that is suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. This vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. The engineered RBD is presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This work provides a promising platform for the development of a cost-effective vaccine for the global response to COVID-19. (Show more)

The study of the role of the ALK/ALKALS in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is of high interest for the understanding of human diseases. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/ALKALS are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the eye. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/ALKALS by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. Our findings have implications for the understanding of the role of ALK/ALKALS in human diseases.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis is one of the most devastating pathogens in human history, and its emergence is thought to have been a key factor in the collapse of the Bronze Age. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. We find that the plague bacterium was likely present in Eurasia as early as the Neolithic, and that it underwent a series of evolutionary steps before it became adapted to the flea vector. We also find that the plague bacterium was much more geographically widespread during this period than previously thought, and that it was likely present in Europe before the spread of the flea. These data provide insights into the early evolution of this pathogen and its relationship with its vector, which are important for understanding its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The conversion of grasslands to agricultural production has been a major driver of the current global carbon (C) cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has resulted in the release of 1.2 Pg C to the atmosphere since 1700. In this study, we show that the management of grasslands can be used to sequester C in the soil. We demonstrate that the management of grasslands with rotational grazing can increase soil C storage by 18 to 29% over 29 y of management. This study highlights the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provides a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover and spread of novel viruses in wildlife. We developed a framework to identify risk factors and estimate the zoonotic potential of wildlife viruses. We then applied this framework to a large dataset of viruses from wildlife and humans. Our results provide a comprehensive assessment of the risk of spillover and spread of zoonotic viruses in wildlife and can be used to inform research and public health interventions. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be updated over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This tool will be of interest to policy makers and health scientists.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals and is often used to infer the identity of the pollinator. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that this trait is convergent in two other plant species visited by vertebrates, suggesting that the red nectar trait is a widespread and important adaptation for vertebrate-visited plants. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of nectar color and the role of alkaloids in the evolution of floral signals. This work also highlights the importance of alkaloids in the evolution of floral signals and the convergence of traits in two different vertebrate-pollinated species. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from the late 5th/early 6th century AD in Bavaria, Germany. We show that the genetic ancestry of these women is highly heterogeneous, and that some of them have a genetic ancestry that is not found in modern Europeans. This is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, who have a genetic ancestry that is not found in modern Europeans. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, were investigated. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. We describe a large-scale, resource-scarce setting metagenomic pathogen surveillance study of undifferentiated febrile illness. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible and cost-effective approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We demonstrate that mNGS can identify vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, and that the early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak. We also show that mNGS can identify risk factors associated with undifferentiated febrile illness. Our study provides a blueprint for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We anticipate that mNGS pathogen surveillance will be a key component of the global response to emerging pathogens. This will be particularly important in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, where mNGS can be used to rapidly identify and respond to other undifferentiated febrile illnesses. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the replication of genetic information was accomplished by RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the replication of nucleic acids has been accomplished by proteins, but the replication of functional RNA molecules has been elusive. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a method for measuring the physical appearance of neighborhoods that can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to be involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis. Here we show that the xan BGC isocyanide products bind copper and that the presence of copper impacts the cellular copper content. We also show that the isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties and that copper can be used to remove their antimicrobial activity. These results suggest that the xan BGC isocyanides are involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes. This is the first report of a fungal natural product with copper-binding properties. The presence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in the control of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. Tridymite is a common product of silicic volcanism, and it is also a common product of diagenesis of high-SiO2 glass and/or precipitated silica. Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in response to the ongoing warming of the atmosphere.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is unable to induce colitis in a transfer model. This subset is dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by the degeneration of motor neurons, which are the key cells for voluntary muscle control. The disease is caused by mutations in genes that encode motor neuron proteins, and also by the expansion of a repeat in a gene that encodes a protein involved in RNA processing. We now report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which are the cells that cause disease in ALS. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will be a major advance in ALS research and in the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of the vector is a critical component of the infectious cycle of many pathogens. In this study, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector, the Ixodes scapularis tick, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by altering the composition of the peritrophic matrix, which is a barrier to bacterial colonization. We also show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by altering the composition of the gut microbiota, which is a critical obstacle for the pathogen. These data provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The presence of a pygostyle, a short tail bone, is a defining feature of modern birds. However, the origin of the pygostyle is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early members of the group. Here, we describe a basal member of the group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the avian tail. Our study increases the known diversity of early pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail. Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also presents evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is prevalent in many vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the development of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) is important for the development of new therapies. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn regulates expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG, which is a key regulator of BCSC phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the development of BCSCs. Thus, our findings suggest that ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism for the development of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. (Show more)

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was difficult to tell the animal species from which it came. We used a simple and objective method to identify the animal species from which the parchment was made. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is based on five ash beds, each of which is constrained by a single ash particle. The age model is consistent with a trigger/kill mechanism, and the carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction. The age model is also consistent with a role for the global environmental perturbation hypothesis, but the carbon cycle variability is a necessary component of any model of the extinction. The age model is also consistent with a role for the Siberian Traps, but the carbon cycle variability is a necessary component of any model of the extinction. The age model is also consistent with a role for the carbon cycle in the recovery of the biota, but the carbon cycle variability is a necessary component of any model of the extinction. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and involves multiple factors. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) controls the balance of inflammatory responses by dismissing CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of RORα in the regulation of intestinal inflammation. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a range of more open conformations of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This study provides a detailed structural comparison of the D614G mutant spike and may help to inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 79.6 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the importance of addressing structural inequalities in order to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and improve health outcomes in the United States.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these effects is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, rather than climate, is the dominant driver of future changes in global fire activity. This has important implications for the carbon cycle, as it means that the effects of climate change on the carbon cycle may be less important in the future than previously thought. Our results suggest that, in order to mitigate climate change, we need to focus on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, rather than on climate mitigation strategies that focus on reducing fire activity.

The provision of nutrients to specific microbial communities in the body is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate their health. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of host–microbe interactions. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to specific microbial communities in the body may be a more general strategy used by animals to regulate their health. (Show more)

We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is illustrated with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We expect our method to be of interest to researchers in many domains, including psychology, sociology, and medicine. Our method can be applied to structured and unstructured text, and can be used to model topics in a variety of domains. Our method can also be used to identify gender biases in topics. The Black Death, which originated in Asia, was introduced into Europe in the 14th century. This event marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before the first European outbreaks. We also show that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe on several occasions, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y, suggesting that the disease was not established in Europe before the bacterium was reintroduced. Our results suggest that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was the result of multiple, independent introductions, rather than a single introduction. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague pandemic. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that leads to rapid death. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the sea star’s natural enemies. This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for a mass mortality event of a marine invertebrate and that it is transmitted by the natural enemies of the host.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations. In addition, we show that the history of Madagascar is also reflected in the genomic diversity, with a strong influence of geography on the genetic structure of the population. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other viruses that cause diseases in humans. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines, and may be useful in the development of new therapeutics. Our approach can also be extended to other protein-based molecules, such as enzymes and receptors.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is based on the assessments of many crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We show that the CPC is a robust and stable model that can be used to predict crop yields with high accuracy. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how the CPC can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC is a valuable source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This information can be used to improve agricultural production and management decisions.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order of presentation of words in a sentence. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to the order of presentation of words in a sentence. We also show that it is sensitive to context, which makes it suitable for binding linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.
