The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to model, because the process is not reversible. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is also a major evolutionary event, which has a measurable signature in the genomes. We show that the transition to parasitic lifestyles relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in over a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. We also show that the probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of human influence on the recent intensification of drought in SSA. It also provides a useful tool for the development of drought management strategies in the region. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the study of materials. The first known example of a quasicrystal in nature was found in a meteorite, the Khatyrka meteorite, which fell in the Russian Republic of Karelia in 1979. The discovery of the first anthropogenic quasicrystal, in a test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test, in 1945, was a major advance in the history of materials science. Here, we report the discovery of a third example of an anthropogenic quasicrystal, in red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that drives life. The biosynthesis of the pigments that capture the energy is a key step. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll pigments is a key step in this process. This reaction is catalyzed by a cyclase enzyme, which has been difficult to study because of the complexity of the reaction. Here we show that the formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll pigments is catalyzed by three different enzymes in plants, cyanobacteria, and bacteria. These results provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neuro

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought years is more than doubled if they occur when conditions are warm. These findings have important implications for California and other regions that are experiencing or will experience increasing drought risk in a warming world.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key component of store-operated Ca2+ entry, a signaling pathway that regulates a broad range of cellular functions. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, leading to hematological abnormalities and myopathy. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a model for the development of therapies for patients with dysregulated CRAC channel signaling in other diseases. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is a result of the active release of aggregates from the site of synthesis and their uptake by other neurons. This mechanism of spreading is distinct from the spread of misfolded proteins in neurodegenerative diseases, and may be a common mechanism of spreading of protein aggregates in other neurodegenerative diseases.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of the bat salivary gland in the evolution of the immune system and the potential for the use of MTX as a therapeutic agent for the treatment of viral diseases. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of cancer, and a strategy for the treatment of DLBCL. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or treatment. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for exploring the physics of many-body systems, including the study of topological insulators, superconductors, and quantum phase transitions. The device can be used to study the physics of cold atoms in a 2D geometry, including the study of topological insulators, superconductors, and quantum phase transitions. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that lived below the surface of the water. The study of the aquatic flowering plants of the Cretaceous period, such as Montsechia, is important for understanding the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using genetic sequences from living organisms. However, viruses are often present in the human body for long periods of time, and it is possible to study the evolution of viruses in ancient human remains. Here we present 10 ancient B19V sequences, which are dated to between ∼12.6 and ∼0.5 kya. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has risen over the last century, and this rise is expected to continue into the future. The rate of this rise is expected to slow in the coming decades, but then to accelerate as the oceans continue to warm. This work provides a detailed analysis of the acceleration of sea level over the last 25 y, which is the time period for which we have the most precise satellite altimeter data. We find that the acceleration is not linear in time, as was previously thought, but is best described by a quadratic. This work provides a more accurate estimate of the rate of sea level rise in the coming decades.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate of tryptophan synthase with indole, a reaction that is the defining step in the mechanism of this enzyme. The results provide a detailed picture of the reaction pathway, including the role of crystallographic waters in the reaction, and highlight the importance of the active-site environment in determining the outcome of the reaction. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography in providing mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the development of remdesivir for a clinical trial in humans. The provision of nutrients to specific microbial communities in the body is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbiotic microbiota. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is linked to the maturation of the symbiotic organ. This glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which is essential for the production of bioluminescence. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their microbiota. This article is protected by copyright. This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools by changing the way teachers think about students. This is a major finding, because suspension rates are a major predictor of future criminality and unemployment. The study also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline through a brief, online intervention. This is a major finding, because teachers are the most important influence on students’ behavior. The study has implications for the way we think about the causes of crime and for the way we think about the role of teachers in society.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are the major cause of DNA damage and mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be useful for the development of new strategies for the prevention of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We found that the first cleavages severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Our findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These results also suggest that the first cleavages may be promising targets for antiviral drug development.

The food system is a major contributor to environmental degradation and a leading cause of global disease burden. The food choices people make are a key driver of these trends. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a substantial impact on meal selection. This is a simple and cost-effective way to promote more sustainable diets and improve population health. The approach could be easily implemented in other settings, such as hospitals and schools. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian options available in catering operations could be a powerful way to promote more sustainable diets and improve population health. This approach is simple, cost-effective, and scalable.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer and other diseases. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with a high mortality rate and a lack of effective treatments. The role of the viral accessory protein ORF8 in the disease severity of COVID-19 is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This study provides a molecular basis for the unique immune evasion and disease severity of SARS-CoV-2. This work also provides a foundation for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental factor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, which in turn up-regulate aquaporin-4 (AQP4) expression and water influx into astrocytes, leading to edema. This study provides a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to miss any. We also don’t want to be too conservative and miss important associations because we are too liberal. This paper describes a way to address this challenge.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the repair of ischemic tissues. However, the generation of ECs is difficult, and the number of factors that induce ECs is unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of ischemic disorders. Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a large family of transmembrane receptors that are activated by extracellular ligands. In the last decade, two additional RTKs have been identified as oncogenes: anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). Here, we show that zebrafish, a model organism, can be used to study the physiological function of these two RTKs. We show that zebrafish deficient in Ltk display a severe defect in iridophore patterning, which is completely rescued by a specific ligand of Ltk. This study establishes a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrates that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system to study the function of RTKs in vivo and to understand the role of their ligands in human diseases. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well established, the underlying mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still to be fully elucidated. Here, we show that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune system, is required for the maintenance of insulin secretion in β-cells. Our study provides a new perspective on the role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis and insulin secretion. This study also establishes pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral packaging and could lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change: the economic theory of human capital, the tipping theory of urban change, and the invasion theory of urban change. Our results also suggest that the physical dynamics of cities are more complex than previously thought.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study also provides a model for the study of the evolution of insect–plant interactions. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the infection of cells of the nervous system is likely a key factor. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model is able to reproduce the observed within-host dynamics of ZIKV, and we use the model to assess the effect of an antiviral treatment and the potential of a polymerase inhibitor, favipiravir, to reduce the time to clearance of ZIKV in the blood. Our results suggest that favipiravir could be a promising treatment for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a consequence of the interaction between the host and its algal symbionts, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn leads to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a tight barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its barrier function, leading to systemic infections and death. Here, we show that the microbiome can regulate the activity of the intestinal epithelium, and that the epithelium can regulate the activity of the microbiome. Our work identifies a mechanism that can be exploited to control the activity of the epithelium and prevent cancer. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to this therapy is heterogeneous. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, features that are associated with cancer stemness. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with chemotherapy alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a climate response. This is a unique and unexpected link between the atmosphere and the surface, and it explains the timing of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that these populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are a key source of food security, and to prioritize conservation efforts to protect biodiversity. Our analysis also highlights the need for improved management of inland fisheries, which are often neglected in policy and planning. Our results underscore the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, and the need to protect these ecosystems for the benefit of future generations.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is designed to deliver a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is lost during development and is not restored in the adult. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a platform for the discovery of novel genes that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system can be restored in response to injury. This study also provides a model for the study of regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are necessary for sexual reproduction. The process of recombination, which is the primary mechanism of genetic variation in eukaryotes, is highly variable across the genome. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and show that the distribution of recombination is highly similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the function of the brain. Here, we show that the default mode network is the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects. In Parkinson’s disease, this network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network function was assessed by quantifying the expression of the resting state networks in healthy subjects and in patients with Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease. In healthy subjects, the dominant resting state network was associated with reduced cerebral blood flow. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this network was associated with increased blood flow. In Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant resting state network was associated with reduced blood flow. These results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. Here we show that the yeast genome contains a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We find that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for understanding the function of NAD+ in the cell. (Show more)

The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes is a relatively new field. In this study, we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years in people with diabetes, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit development is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse mixture of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that are organized into distinct cell types, each of which is thought to be involved in different aspects of navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that neurons that are thought to be involved in different aspects of navigation are not completely segregated, but instead show some degree of mixing. This finding suggests that the organization of MEC cell types is more complex than previously thought. It also provides a platform for future studies of the functional organization of MEC. Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and with the development of motor and nonmotor symptoms. Here, we show that the dopamine-containing neurons are part of a larger system that includes the striatum and that the disease is associated with the loss of these systems. We also show that the dopamine-containing neurons are part of specialized integrative units within the system.

We are social creatures, and we often judge the quality of our social interactions by how well we feel connected to one another. But how do we know when we are feeling connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We found that people feel more connected to the degree that their partner responds quickly to them, and that this signal is used by third-party listeners to judge the quality of the connection between two people. Our findings suggest that we may be able to use our own response times as a way to judge the quality of our social interactions.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for the regulation of heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure and other hemodynamic factors. In this study, we show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the generation of the heart rate. Our results suggest that STIM1 is a key regulator of SAN function and may be a target for the treatment of heart rate disorders. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivory has not been well established. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA signaling may be a general mechanism for plant resistance against insect herbivory. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivory. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the treatment of phenylketonuria.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. Our results suggest that memory is supported by a dynamic system that is sensitive to the context of the current state and the history of the system. This system is not dependent on the presence of feedback or synaptic plasticity, and it is not limited to the storage of single events.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up a new avenue for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and could be extended to other biological systems. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in lakes that are large relative to their watersheds. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds, which could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of complex systems in the real world, where the dynamics of many interacting elements are biased toward states that are highly unlikely in equilibrium.

This study provides a detailed description of the mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other neuropsychiatric disorders on the brain’s electrical activity.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a period of rapid climate change, and it is important to understand the processes that have driven past abrupt climate changes. Here, we present a study of a past abrupt climate change that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the climate change was accompanied by a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that the climate change was accompanied by a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a promising tool for reducing tropical deforestation, but its effectiveness will depend on the extent to which certification is adopted in forested regions and the implementation of strict requirements to avoid peat. The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of an individual. In this study, we show that the interaction of multiple alleles can produce a modular system of sexual traits, where the same genetic locus can produce different phenotypes in different individuals. This modularity is a result of the interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, which can be a consequence of polygenic sex determination. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be a consequence of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, impact the levels of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A. These findings have implications for the retina and other tissues challenged by reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of reactive intermediates.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to be lost during the process. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, can evolve into specialists on different prey types, and that these transitions are linked to the evolution of their specialized feeding structures. Our findings contribute to a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification, and help understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution, and the fossil record is sparse between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we show that a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, was present ∼1.42 My old in a fossil from East Africa. This provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of cancer, and a strategy for the treatment of DLBCL. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets, particularly in terms of vitamin A adequacy. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. In particular, the use of heavy machinery has led to the compaction of the soil, which is a major threat to soil health and productivity. We show that the use of heavy machinery has led to the compaction of the soil to a depth of 1 m, which is now a major threat to soil ecological functioning. We also show that the use of heavy machinery has led to the compaction of the soil to a depth of 1 m, which is now a major threat to soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the use of heavy machinery by prehistoric sauropods may have had a similar effect on the land, suggesting that the roaming of these giants may have had a major impact on the productivity of the land.
